titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Clifford K. Berryman cartoon collection, 1899-1949 MS2024
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:21:35 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection consist of cartoons (209), Christmas cards (12), and facsimiles of cartoons (3), all drawn by Clifford K. Berryman. The cartoons with identified dates span the years 1899-1949, thus exemplifying Berryman's work over much of his career. Berryman was employed as a cartoonist by the Washington Post from 1891-1970 and by the Washington Star from 1907-49. There are only a handful of cartoons which were composed before 1907, when Berryman left the Washington Post to draw for the Washington Star. Conversely, a substantial portion of the cartoons (at least 50) date from the last 3 years (1946-1949) of Berryman's long career. About 135 of the items have been date-identified while the remainder are undated.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Clifford K. Berryman, cartoon collection, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: In 1977, Berryman's daughter, Florence Seville Berryman, donated this collection of Berryman cartoons to The George Washington University. 1983, Ms. Berryman also donated Gridiron Nights and Report from Tokyo (illustrated by Berryman), and other art books.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, the donor has assigned the copyright in her works to The George Washington University; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For activities that the researcher determines fall under fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Please contact Special Collections if the copyright status of the materials you wish to reuse is unclear. Staff will provide additional information.

For re-use of materials in the collection not created by the donor, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights, determining if the intended re-use falls under fair use, and obtaining approval from the copyright holder if the intended use does not fall under fair use. For such materials, researchers do not need anything further from The George Washington University's Special Collections Research Center.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In April 1949, around his eightieth birthday, Clifford K. Berryman received a letter from then-President Harry S. Truman. Though Berryman had been vice president of the Association of Oldest Inhabitants of the District, Truman found Berryman to be truly "ageless and timeless." In an often-quoted passage, Truman went further to write that "Presidents, Senators, and even Supreme Court Justices come and go but the [Washington] Monument and Berryman stand." Only seven months later, the "Dean of American Cartoonists" collapsed in the lobby of the Washington Star, on his way to work. On December 11, 1949 he passed away at home, at 2114 Bancroft Place, NW, of a heart ailment. He was buried in Glenwood Cemetery.

Clifford Kennedy Berryman was born in Kentucky on April 2, 1869, one of James Thomas and Sallie (Church) Berryman's eleven children. James Berryman was a commission merchant, farmer, and/or grain dealer who entertained family members and neighbors with sketches of "hillbillies" in their hometown. Clifford inherited his father's talent, and after he graduated from Prof. Henry's School for Boys in Versailles, KY, he was appointed as a draftsman to the United States Patent Office in Washington, D.C. From 1886 to 1891, Berryman delineated patent entries for $30 per month. He began to submit cartoons to the Washington Post, and in 1891 he became an understudy to the Post's cartoonist, George Y. Coffin (some of whose cartoons are also at Gelman Library). When Coffin died in 1896, Berryman replaced him. Berryman stayed with the Post until 1907, when he was hired by the Washington Star, which had a larger circulation at the time. Clifford Berryman drew political cartoons for the Star for the next 42 years, up until his death.

Commenting on Clifford K. Berryman's work, politicians, artists, and reference books note that Berryman cartoons lack the maliciousness that has been a part of American politics throughout the twentieth century. Himself a Democrat, Berryman satirized political figures from both the Democratic party and the G.O.P.. Though he is best known for the November 16, 1902 Washington Post cartoon "Drawing The Line In Mississippi" which portrayed a "teddy bear" for the first time, Berryman's copious work has earned recognition in many venues. In 1944, he won the Pulitzer Prize for editorial cartooning for "But Where Is The Boat Going?", which showed then-president Franklin D. Roosevelt and various government officials trying to steer, in opposite directions, the "USS Manpower Mobilization". The magazine Journalism & Mass Communication Educator, in its Spring 1998 issue, listed Clifford Berryman (along with Thomas Nast and Pat Oliphant) as some of ten cartoonists who have made an "outstanding contribution to American journalism".

In July 1893, Berryman married Kate Geddes, the daughter of engraver George Washington Durfee. The couple had three children: Mary Belle, who died as an infant; Florence Seville (an art critic), and John Thomas (also a Pulitzer-Prize winning cartoonist). Alongside his work at the drawing board, Berryman was an active member of the Washington Heights Presbyterian Church at 1862 Kalorama Road. He was also the first cartoonist to become a member of the Gridiron Club, and was its president in 1926.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consist of cartoons (209), Christmas cards (12), and facsimiles of cartoons (3), all drawn by Clifford K. Berryman. The cartoons with identified dates span the years 1899-1949, thus exemplifying Berryman's work over much of his career. Berryman was employed as a cartoonist by the Washington Post from 1891-1907 and by the Washington Star from 1907-49. There are only a handful of cartoons which were composed before 1907, when Berryman left the Washington Post to draw for the Washington Star. Conversely, a substantial portion of the cartoons (at least 50) date from the last 3 years (1946-1949) of Berryman's long career. About 135 of the items have been date-identified while the remainder are undated.

In large part, Berryman's subjects are American Presidents and political figures, as well as political events and controversies of national import. There are a number of cartoons depicting former Presidents Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Harry S. Truman, as well as presidential candidates like Alfred E. Smith. Congressmen and state government leaders also make frequent appearances in Berryman's work. The cartoons broach nationally debated problems and interests such as: drought, farm relief, and food prices; representation of the District of Columbia in Congress; labor strikes and legislation; campaigning and elections; political patronage; European coronations; the America's Cup; and the Atomic Bomb.
Florence Berryman was an alumnae of The George Washington University (class of 1924), and her father received an honorary MA from the University.

Berryman drew thousands of cartoons, often giving them away to libraries and political figures who requested or exhibited them. Substantial collections can therefore be found in a number of cultural institutions in Washington D.C., where Berryman lived and worked for more than 50 years including the Library of Congress and National Archives. American chief executives from Grover Cleveland to Harry Truman were known to collect Berryman's work, so archives documenting the presidency are also likely to own some Berryman cartoons.

odd.head: Collection note
odd.p: Other than the Christmas cards, nearly all of the Berryman cartoons range in size from 13 x 15" to 16" x 20" and except for the Christmas cards and cartoon facsimiles

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The following collection contains a George Washington University bookplate designed by Clifford Berryman, University Historical Materials RG0031 Series 13 Oversize Box 1.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Shows a man riding a donkey and carrying a flag labeled "Democracy" running on a treadmill labeled "Aguinaldo Platform"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a factory with sign "Closed Today Only" and female figure leading the working man away

did.unittitle: "John Bull's Real Work Is Just Beginning"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows figure representing England leading an orchestra in playing "God Save The King"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows Ebenezer Scrooge and a young boy

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows George Washington (?) approaching a house

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows 17th century family enjoying Christmas dinner. Man in card is reported to be Samuel Pepys.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows Santa Claus as a pied piper, leading children and the famous teddy bear "to you". Children are wearing sashes labeled "Good Cheer", "Health", etc.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows Mark Twain toasting

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows 10 persons/ideas which are "gone with the wind", including "Mr. Pickwick", "Selassie", "Horace", "Patrick Henry", "W.S. Gilbert", "Liberty", "Erasmus", "King George", and "Old Spain"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows teddy beat sitting on Uncle Sam's lap, saying "What better place to have a Merry Christmas?"; Strewn around Uncle Sam's feet and armchair are headlines about the war in Europe

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Christmas card, shows teddy bear climbing lamppost at Bancroft place, pointing to Berryman's new home

odd.head: General
odd.p: This is a Christmas card. Purchased by SCRC 2/14/2011 (accession 2011.012).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows J.P. Morgan on his knees before Theodore Roosevelt, begging "Save Us, Mr. President, Save Us!"; teddy bear is weeping and "R.R. Magnates" wait in the background

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure and Uncle Sam looking proudly at a framed motto which says "We'll Dig the Ditch or Bust" (probably in reference to Panama Canal); teddy bear looks on with pickax and shovel saying, "You Bet!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Miss Democracy" trying to decide which dinner table to sit at: William J. Bryan's, ? Parker's, or ? Hearst's

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows footsteps leading to the canebrake, and newspaper/sketch/photograph men and dogs in pursuit; also shows an African American leading a bear cub in chains

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows King Carlos being tugged by an "Absolutist" and a "Revolutionist"

did.unittitle: "A Suggestion To The House District Committee"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows persons being ski-lifted to Union Station over a field of snow

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam assuring elderly bureaucrats that the "Dismissal of Elder Clerks" is "Merely An Annual Spectre"; a teddy bear asks them "Who's Afraid?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows William Jennings Bryan courting "Democracy" as Wilson and others peek through a window

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Democracy" being strangled by a serpent "Bryanism" with reptiles "Socialism" and "Populism" close at hand; she cries "Oh, For A St. Patrick!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows William H. Taft riding the "Taft Panama Special"; an avalanche blocks the tracks as he asks "I Wonder If That's An Omen?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "General Apathy" being driven back from the White House by Theodore Roosevelt as teddy bear looks on

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Nebraska" pinning a corsage to the breast of William H. Taft; a note at Taft's feet says "Dear Nebraskans- Treat Taft To The Best You Can Hand Out"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows huge "Steel Trust Infant Industry" nursing on "High Protective Tariff" as Uncle Sam and teddy bear look on. Andrew Carnegie opines, "Really, It Can Get Along Without It!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Theodore Roosevelt and teddy bear being shielded from storm of "Political Patronage" by an umbrella "Classified Service"; also shows fourth-class postmasters rushing to the umbrella as congressmen throw up their arms

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Theodore Roosevelt finding a trophy from the "Late Ananias Club" on his Sagamore Hill doorstep

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows jungle animals looking off into the distance, Giraffe saying "It's The Big Smoke, Pals!"; a "News Notes" indicates that this illustration relates to Theodore Roosevelt's arrival at Mombassa on April 21

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows decayed "Ananias Club" clubhouse and all its "Annexes" up for sale

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows King Alphonso of Spain on throne, looking at American headlines which ignore the situation in Spain

did.unittitle: "The Czar's Pleasure Trip To Sunny Italy"

odd.p: shows Czar and army legions marching in Italy

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified sailor figure gazing at "America's Cup" which is locked in a display case

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows well-dressed "Beef Trust" pointing to poor farmer as "The Guilty Cause of High Prices"

did.unittitle: "It May Come To This If The Upward Price Of Hogs Continues"

odd.p: shows hogs pulling the carriage of a wealthy man

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows politicos walking arm in arm

did.unittitle: "Squash Center Shows Interest In Public Questions"

did.unittitle: "A Spring Caller At The White House"

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure carrying a large block of ice on a hot day as children follow him

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows disappointed man looking at seed catalogues of "giant" potatoes, "king" carrots and other vegetables

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Lafollette (?) trying to use string and a "Big Stick" to trip William H. Taft and teddy bear, who are sledding down the "nomination track"

did.unittitle: "Suggested As A Design To Perpetuate The Unbossed Saratoga Convention"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows statue of unidentified figure turning his back on kneeling, pleading politicians

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Rip Van Winkle reading the standings of baseball clubs for the 1912 season; he is amazed that the Washington Senators are in second place

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows William J. Bryan holding off applications for positions to look at Cuba's amnesty bill

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a chicken saying to a turkey that a chicken is "...too valuable to kill". A headline announces that the price of eggs "continues to soar"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Woodrow Wilson under the "Administration Umbrella" urging a "Democratic Insurgent" to come out of the rain

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Bull holding headlines and American flags; he comments "My Word! I Never Thought I'd Enjoy This Celebration So Jolly Well"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows classical style woman placing wreaths on headstones marked "1776" "1812" "1846" "1861" "1898" and "1918"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Peace" dropping an olive branch as shells burst in the sky and ocean

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Al Smith, Mc Adoo, Glass, Ritchies, Reed, and Pomerene with egg baskets as Calvin Coolidge sits and looks on

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Al Smith leading a woman through a stream rather than over the "Dry Plank". The Dry Plank is "Slippery" he says.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Al Smith teaching a donkey that Smith is "The Leader Of His Party"

did.unittitle: "The Lady---'Where Are The Guys That Said It Couldn't Be Done?'"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows woman walking a tightrope holding "Temporary Chairman Barkley" in one hand and "Permanent Chairman Shouse" in the other

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam and teddy bear leading money out of the "hiding place" in an anti-hoarding campaign"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Al Smith holding up a placard "The Platform At The Coming Convention Should Be Clear and Concise And Tell The People Just What Democracy Is!"; a donkey studying books on democracy by Bryan, Jefferson and others remarks "You Tell Me, Al!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows old women commending "Newt" on his opinion that "Congress should be kept in session all the time"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Franklin D. Roosevelt leading an ancient man who represents "Restore The Purchasing Power To The Farmer"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows farmwoman "Congress" plucking the feathers of "Government Expenditures" chicken

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Franklin D. Roosevelt as a doctor seeing a sick farmer/patient representing the "Middle West". The Middle West asks, "Yes Doc, They All Say I Need Attention But What Is This Remedy Of Yours?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Manager Farley" as a barker, showing boys into a tent of "Numberless Political Performances"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows lumberjacks "House" and "Senate" sawing the log of "U.S. Problems". They tell Franklin D. Roosevelt, "You Tell 'Em, Frank!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Herbert Hoover gleefully fishing as headlines of "Farmers Revolt" "Farley Fights Tammany" and others lie across his lap

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a racoon "House" sitting on the "Legislative Branch" begging Franklin D. Roosevelt not to shoot

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows FDR, Uncle Sam and teddy bear watching glumly as Finland crosses the finish line of "June 15". Belgium, England, Italy and France all have their backs turned to the line

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Hitler, Stalin, and Italy in the "Dictator's Club" smoking and discussing how FDR can "Get In Step"

did.unittitle: "An Up To Date Admiral Nelson Goes Into Action!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Farley on the "S.S. Democratic Committee" commenting "All Democrats Look Alike To Me!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows taxpayers, Congress, and the military giving up cash, power, and services, respectively, as a laborer asserts "But I'll Never Give Up The Right To Strike!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows FDR, the "GOP" (as an elephant) and "Democracy" (as a donkey) on the same team, "...Bound To Score", "Aid To Britain". Shows Wheeler and Nye trying to block the goal with the "Isolation" stick

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Winston Churchill in a wrestling ring being mauled by "Japan" (Hirohito?), Mussolini, and Hitler. Clark, Wheeler, and Nye are behind the ropes, making various accusations against Churchill and Great Britain

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows cross-eyed voter being urged in different directions by Franklin D. Roosevelt, Norman Thomas, Al Smith, "N.D.B." "C.C." Garner "Hiram J." Herbert Hoover Ritchie and an unidentified figure

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "D.C." sitting on a curb near the Capitol, listening to rhetoric championing democracy and reviling dictatorship; near him is a headline "Senate Subcommittee Decide Not To Report National Representation Amendment" and he comments "They Do A Lot Of Talking About Democracy, Don't They?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows taxpayer buried under a pile of ominous headlines as "Congress" prepares to declare a limited emergency. The taxpayer says to Uncle Sam, "I Passed That Stage In 1933"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stimson trying to take the new war department building into Arlington. Franklin D. Roosevelt, just coming out of Union Station, catches Stimson in the act. Teddy bear says, "I'm Glad You're Back, Mr. President. They're About To Steal All The Furniture"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Nomura and Kurusu in a revolving door "War Exit-Peace Exit". Hull tells them they "Have To Decide Where they, Want To Get Out"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stalin and Hitler putting up wallpaper marked "Kerch" and "Kharkov". Stalin is tugging on the paper and saying "Now's A Good Time For Somebody To Knock Down The Ladder" that Hitler is standing on

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Wallace painting a portrait of Uncle Sam holding a horn of plenty. Wickard is telling him that the painting "Looks Mighty Nice" but that "It's Going To Be A Hard Winter"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows FDR and Dewey dumping "Bureaucracy" "Extravagance" "Isolationists" and others overboard

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Q. Public loading a cannon with a "7th War Loan" amid the spent shells of the 1st through 6th war loans and a destroyed Germany; Uncle Sam urges to keep firing at "Tokyo" with the remark "No Time To Cease Firing Yet"; teddy bear looks at a map of Japan

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Churchill and Atlee beside an old car "Britain's Coalition Movement"; Atlee tells Churchill "It Served Its Purpose. It's Time We Got Started On A New Model"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Clement Atlee entering in on a meeting between Truman and Stalin; Stalin continues "Now As I Was Saying When So Rudely Interrupted"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stimson showing Truman the "Atomic Bomb Report" of "Greatest Achievement Of The Combined Efforts Of Science, Industry, Labor And The Military In All History"; the frightened John Q. Public presents the problem "How To Make People Be Decent To Each Other" and asks Truman to "P-p-p-lease Made Those Scientists Solve This One Real Q-q-q-q-quick!"

did.unittitle: "The Cabinet Meets To Discuss Sending An Ambassador To Mars"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Truman and members of the cabinet dressed in Mercury costumes and seated at a round table with "Split Atoms" as the centerpiece

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam hoisting the flags "V-E Day" and "V-J Day" up a flagpole, amid graveyard crosses marked "Midway," "Iwo Jima," and others; teddy bear is holding an olive branch, and Truman comments "And This Time We Are Going To Win The Peace, Too!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows DeGaulle, Attlee, Stalin and Chiang Kai-Shek with fire hoses plugged into a hydrant marked "Lend Lease"; Truman is turning a wrench on the hydrant

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Q. Public sitting on the steps of the Supreme Court looking a headline that reads "French Vote To Change Constitution". He wonders why "They Went To All That Trouble"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Schwellenbach asking Frances Perkins "What's He Got That We Haven't Got?" as he holds up the headline "Movie Industry Offers Krug $75,000 A Year As Labor Director"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Brewster, Ferguson, George and Barkley at the "Pearl Harbor Investigation" throwing books at each other

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows GI's overseas exclaiming "I Want To Come Home"; John Q. Public standing on the North American continent, asks "Why?" as strikes burst like bombs around him

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Truman showing John Q. Public various military-related headlines. John Q. Public is scratching his head, saying "It's Hard For Me To See How They Add Up"

did.unittitle: "The House of Representatives Resumes Its Pre-Pearl Harbor Position"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows man with his head stuck like an ostrich in the sand

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Q. Citizen strapped to a rocket "Uncontrolled Prices". "Congress" assures him that "The Laws Of Gravity" will bring him back

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure plugging his ears as a war plane and ships loom on the horizon

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Forrestal overlooking destroyed Naval ships, commenting "Flash This Signal Around The World: They Didn't Get The Navy's Goat"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Truman and unidentified figure with microphones, arguing. Barkley is sitting in between them, holding a large sack "Price Controls" and asking "But Who Is It Always Left Holding The Bag"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a rocket marked "This Rocket Climbed 83 ½ Miles For A New Record" crashing to earth. John Q. Public, holding the tail of the "Food Prices" rocket says, "But Watch Me, Brother"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Q. Voter laughing with the GOP elephant as Hannegan asks "What's Funny...?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam dismayed at all the "Gimme's" bursting around him. Christopher Columbus is climbing up the Washington Monument, saying "I Sure Started Something When I Discovered America."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Mason, Young, and Grant denying responsibility for the "Slum Reclamation Project"; George Washington urges them on, saying "...You've Got A Big Job To Do"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Dewey, Taft, Reece, Bricker, Martin, White, and Vandenburg dining over the turkey "November Elections" as John Q. Public asks "Hey! When Do I Get Paid For The Turkey?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Langer wielding a hatchet and dancing around the "Indian Bureau", a Native American figure which is tied to a pole

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Hannegan and Reece as hens in the "1948 Presidential Candidate Hatchery"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Q. Public outside on a cold day, holding a headline which reads "Admiral Byrd Heads Homeward To Escape Antarctic Ice Belt". Public comments that Byrd is "...Jumping From The Frying Pan Into The Fire"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Congress" with a shotgun "Labor Legislation" at a church with the bridal couple Green and Murray. Green tells Murray "No! Phil, Let Him Shoot"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Dewey awakened to find the screaming orphan "New York Teachers' Unrest" on his doorstep

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows game warden Vandenberg blocking poacher Gael Sullivan, who is hoping to bag politicians into the "Democratic National Committee". The area is "Preserved For A Bi-partisan Foreign Relations Policy"

did.unittitle: "Advice from An Expert In Internal Affairs"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Gromyko chiding Uncle Sam that he is "Interfering In The Internal Affairs Of Greece And Turkey"; behind Gromyko is a bear with a Russian cap; clothing marked "Finland" "Hungary" and etc., strewn about

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows John Bull sitting perturbed in a chair as Wallace speaks at a BBC microphone. Bull muses "The War-The Blitz-Empire Liquidation-Blizzards-Famine-Floods-And Now Henry Wallace"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a farmer "House Appropriations Committee" tending the field "Voice Of America" instead of the overgrown "Waste" and "Extravagance". Uncle Sam asks him "Hey, Aren't You In The Wrong Patch?"

did.unittitle: "It's Going To Be The Most Exciting Thing Since Ben Hur"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows charioteers Taft and Martin riding the "Republican Legislative Program" and whipping the elephant GOP. They are on a treadmill, trying to reach "July Adjournment"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stassen holding up a sign "The Voice Of Stalin As Relayed By Me"; in the background is Stalin, leaning back in a chair, saying "Cooperation? It's Wonderful!" and Taber gagging the mouth of Uncle Sam who is the "Voice of America."

did.unittitle: "Too Many Broths May Spoil the Cook"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Congress" trying to fit the pot "Health Insurance" on a stove already filled with "Voice Of America," "Labor Bill", "Tax Reduction", and other pots

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Truman tripping an elephant "GOP" whose egg basket "Tax Reduction" spills over; "You'll Be Sorry!" says the GOP

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stalin blowing rings of smoke around Uncle Sam

did.unittitle: "Who Said Marathon Racing Was A Dull Sport?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Tax Reduction Bill" running back and forth between Congress and the White House, as John Q. Public watches from bleacher seats

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Warren and Dewey at the "Conference of Governors"; Warren asks Dewey "Do You Find It Hard To Keep Your Mind On Gubernatorial Problems These Days?"; Dewey responds, "There Are Some Distractions"

did.unittitle: "Now We Can Share Our Blessings With The World"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Congress amid a congestion of airplanes, buses, cars, and people, all running away from the Capitol building

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows William Green, president of the AFL-CIO putting up a sign "Labor Will Defeat Taft If Picked By GOP." Dewey and Taft, behind Green, remark "Don't Start Counting Chickens Tom, He'll Try Just As Hard To Defeat You"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Mountbatten giving the country of India to Jinnah and Nehru

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "What Was Forecast" (the Taft-Hartley Bill driving Murray, Lewis, and Green with whips and chains) and "What Seems To Have Happened" (Murray, Lewis, and Green driving the Taft-Hartley bill)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Ecuador shooting off pistols outside the "Inter-American Defense Conference"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Ohio Mother of Presidents" welcoming back Taft, who has come from "The West" and left a trail of "Speeches," behind him; She asks "But Bob, Where Are The Delegates?"

did.unittitle: No title, but on back is "Now What Would You Do About Something That Hasn't Been Offered"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Eisenhower at a desk, surrounded by many offers for the presidency; He comments "The Trouble Is That The People Who Offer Me These Things Do Not Own What They Offer"

did.unittitle: "You Can See Who's Running. But Who Is Ahead?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stassen, Dewey, Warren and Taft on the "1948 Track." Though they are tied in the race, Dewey and Warren are simply standing still, while Stassen and Taft are running

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows the orphans of "Price Control", "Aid To Europe", and "Wage Control" left on the steps of "Congress" "Compliments Of H.S. Truman"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows McKellar, O'Daniel, Taylor, Langer, Moore and Robertson on a raft in the ocean; a flag on the raft says "Senate Opposition To Foreign Aid"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Anderson dressed as Santa Claus, stuffing papers into a sack marked "14000 Names Of Big Speculators"; He comments "Looks Like Somebody Is Going To Get A Christmas Present"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Truman pointing the cannons "State Of The Union" "Economic Report" and "Budget Message" at the Capitol building

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a crowd of people at the White House fence, staring at Truman inside

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a boy "Finland" being shown into an examination room by doctor Stalin; The caps of "Lithuania" "Czechoslovakia" and other bloc countries hang by the door

did.unittitle: "'He Travels The Fastest Who Travels Alone'"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows the knight "European Recovery Program" being followed by Martin, Halleck and Eaton, who hold up riders "Military Aid To China" "Military Aids To Greece" and "Military Aid To Turkey" respectively

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows the "First Robin" and Lewis putting up a sign "The Miners Will Work When Willing And Able And They're Not Too Willing"; John Q. Public looks on and comments "I Guess That Makes It Unanimous"

did.unittitle: "Some of Yesteryear's Rabbits Are Busy Again"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure in academic gown being chased by rabbits holding signs which read "Ike"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Dewey leaving the state of Wisconsin; he tells Stassen and unidentified figure, who are carrying sacks of "Delegates" that he "Hopes He, Shall Return"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Mason, Gen Young and Russ Young examining "D.C." with a "Loyalty Probe"; they remark, "He Looks Harmless Enough But You Never Can Tell"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a donkey and a "Southern Democrat" holding a baby "State's Rights" sitting on a tree limb; Swirling under them is the river "GOP"

did.unittitle: "Decorations Of The Iron Curtain In Honor Of United Nations Week"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Vishinsky painting "NO" on each sheet of the wall

did.unittitle: "Why Not Have A Lifelike Float In The Parade?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Congress" holding "DC" upside-down by the ankles on a float marked "District of Columbia"; As "D.C."'s money falls out of his pockets, three unidentified figures collect it in their hats. Teddy bear carries a flag reading "Taxation Without Representation"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows ten country men talking about the upcoming election, lobbyists, the navy, and other topics

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a goat "Independent Party" holding the coattails of the elephant "G.O.P."; they pass a "News Bulletin" reading "New Liberal Party Proposed At Banquet In New York- To Be Recruited From Liberal Thinkers In Both Old Political Parties"; "Independent Party" comments "It's A Fine Idea.." "But To Hold On To Sure Bread And Butter"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows two unidentified figures bidding their "Bonds" "Salary" and "Dividends" as "Unemployment" asks "How About A Little Something On My Account?"

did.unittitle: "Better Keep Your Eyes Behind You, Harold!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Harold Ickes shouting "Beware Of Those Sixty Families" into a microphone, as a person "C.C.C." rakes "$8400000" in leaves behind him

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Mayor Hylan" dressed in baby clothes; opposite him is a tiger labeled "Tam." which asks him, "Are You Goin' To Bolt?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Hoover pointing to his ear, as crowds of "Eastern Delegation", "Northern Delegation", and other job seekers wait outside; an "Ear Specialist" tells Hoover "It's Nothing Serious! Simply Ear Fatigue Resulting From An Ear Full!"

did.unittitle: "The Boy Stood On The Burning Deck While Eliza Crossed The Ice!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Dave Dubinsky with the "Garment Baby" running cross ice and Charlie Howard diving overboard; John Lewis and the "CIO" are left on deck

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Franklin D. Roosevelt appealing to the Goose "U.S. Business"; Roosevelt says "It's All Right To Lay Golden Eggs But You Watch Your Step"; legions of farmers with their hoes march in the foreground

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Petrillo with a fiddle sitting outside the window of Congress; Congress throws a shoe tagged "House Votes Petrillo Curb 222 to 43"; Petrillo remarks "I Guess I Must Have Hit A Sour Note"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure with sled dogs; penciled in is "Rich'd Byrd"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Lewis, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and LaFollette embracing on a couch; Farley is standing with his hat and bag and remarks "Just One Happy Family. Yeah, I Think It's Time To Go Now!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Fess reading the headline "Man Bests Lion In Fight By Seizing Its Tongue"; meanwhile, a donkey is outside calling for a "Four Year Moratorium For The G.O.P", "Down With The Drought", etc; Fess muses "Wish I Could Get Hold Of That Jackass's Tongue!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Chairman Hawley trying to golf in the "Tariff Revision Golf Links"; he comments "Nothing' But Rough! All The Fairways Seem To Have Been Removed!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Dr. Brookhard trying to hypnotize Herbert Hoover, but Hoover responds "No, I Can't See Any Debenture Delights"; Frazier, looking on, grumbles, "I Also Thought He'd Be Easy"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows farmer Herbert Hoover feeding the GOP hay "Back To The Constitution"; A Progressive goat is eating "New Deal Scraps"; The GOP tells him "Anyhow, It's Better'n You've Been Getting Lately!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Linevitch being stopped from carving up a plate of "Oyama" men by Witte and a "Peace Agreement"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Fiorello LaGuardia holding loaves of bread as the "Director General UNRRA"; an emaciated tiger "Tammany" comments "I Hope He Does Better By Them Than He Did For Me"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows elderly woman commenting "Cal Thinks Well Of The David Family Anyhow!"; on the floor is a headline reading "The Are Now Two Cabinet Members Named Davis"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Franklin D. Roosevelt dressed as blind justice, weighing "Jackson" and "Douglas"; teddy bear tells him, "Better Take That Blindfold Off, Mr. President!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure and a tiger (representing Tammany Hall?) laughing at a picture of Franklin D. Roosevelt, "Our Governor," on the wall

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Congress" looking at a painting of a grand building "President's Proposal To Reorganize Government Housing Agencies"; "John Q. Taxpaper" points to a shack "Our Housing Mess" and asks, "..What Are We Going To Do About This?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows bricklayers "Labor" and "Capital" laying progressively larger bricks of "Prices" and "Wage Increase"; They comment "Maybe We Ought To Stop Now Before It Falls Over!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows soldiers in a trench

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows eagle sitting on the back of a chair marked "NRA" amid a sledgehammer, "code book," and rubble. An unidentified figure is walking into the sunset

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows the Capitol smoking with the "Neutrality Debate" as Daladier, Chamberlain, Stalin and others on the "Western Front" look on

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Molotov with "Estonia" "Slice of Poland" "Latvia" "Lithuania" and "Russian-German Treaty" in his vest pockets. He asks Franklin D. Roosevelt, "What Do You Mean, Sending Me A Letter About Finland? Why You Don't Act Like A Neutral! Look At Me!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Polish Issue" sitting down at the "United Nations Conference" table with Eden, Molotov, and Stettinus

did.unittitle: "Obscuring The View! (With No Apologies To Unsightly Signs)"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a group of roadside advertisements, "Muscle Shoals Measure," "Abolishment Of Lame Duck Sessions," etc. The horizon is marked "No Extra Session"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows automobiles attached to floating blimps marked "D.C. Parking Service"

did.unittitle: "'Windfall Taxation'- New Name But Same Old Sensation!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Wallace, Ickes, Tugwell, and Hopkins in an apple tree. An apple "Increased Taxes", drops on the head of "Tax-Payer" who cries "You Can't Tell Me The Wind's Doin' That!"

did.unittitle: "Teaching The Young Idea How To Shoot (And He Wants To Take Right Hold)" also "1754 Erie St., N.W., Born June 8th 1902 James T. (Heavy) Weight 12 ½ Pounds"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows unidentified figure (probably Berryman) with a baby, showing the baby an autographed portrait of James L. Norris "For National Committeeman"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Blease, Heflin, Simmons, and Ransdell eyeing "America's Cup"; they remark "We Know Just How Sir Thomas Feels!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows tourist and Uncle Sam surrounded by roadside billboards for tires, Carrotine, "The Peoples Candidate John Smith" and others. Uncle Sam wears a placard reading "See America First"

did.unittitle: "Outside Voices" also "Yell, Fellers, Yell! The Chairman Of The Platform Committee Is Reading The Statehood Plank"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Oklahoma" "Arizona" and "New Mexico" laughing outside of the tent "G.O.P. National Convention Chicago"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows several politicos by a train track reading literature left by the "Taft Presidential Special"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows elderly woman "Democracy" looking at rolls of wallpaper marked "States Rights" "Populism" "Recall Of Judges" and others; she comments "Lan' Sakes! I'm Tempted To Paper Every Room With Those Precious Designs"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows large bear "U.S.S.R" pointing at a small man "Finland" and crying to Stalin "Please Make That Great Big Bully Stop Picking On Me!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows H.A. Wallace courting LaFollette; a frustrated "Wisconsin Democracy" stomps off, commenting "Lan' Sakes! You Can Never Guess These Hop-Around Boys!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Jimmy Big Heart Chief Of The Navajos" in Native American dress and brandishing a tomahawk with a heart-shaped blade "Mayor Walker"; "New York" comments "I Knew If You Kept Actin' Like A Wild Indian Somethin' Would Happen To You"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Gene Tunney reading various headlines about fist fights in Congress; he muses "I've Been Thinking All Along That The Rules Committee Should Handle These Affairs"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Mayor Walker" with the placard "We Are Determined To Maintain The Reputation Justly Won Many Years Back As Being The Cleanest, Most Moral City In The World"; behind him is the Tammany tiger, holding a lily, and leaning on Walker, saying "My Jimmy Boy!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows cobwebbed telegraph and telegram from "John Q. Citizen" reading "Uncle Sam, Washington D.C. What has become of the theory that we have a government of the people, by the people, for the people?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Congress napping in a rocking chair beside a falling-down shack "U.S.A."; Truman complains to Uncle Sam and teddy bear "I Wish You'd Speak To Him, Uncle. He'll Do Anything To Please The Neighbors But I Can't Get Him To Do A Thing Around The House"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows various politicians climbing onto the bandwagon "Votes For Women" at the "Last Call"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam at a "U.S. Railway Mail" train taking off his jacket; he decides, "Reckon It's Up To Me To Be A Strike Breaker"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "D.C." shackled to the ball "Taxation Without Representation" and Truman trying to saw at the chain; "D.C." points to "Congress," which is holding the key "Sumners Capper Amendment"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: facsimile, shows Theodore Roosevelt presiding "Dee-Lighted" over the "Canal Route" and teddy bear looking through his binoculars

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Cannon in Shakespearean garb amid trees marked "Cannon"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Calvin Coolidge looking at lengthy sections of the Congressional Record; he remarks "Not A Thought Of My Economy Policy"

did.unittitle: "The President Recently Dug Worms For Fishing"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Calvin Coolidge putting worms "Tax Reduction" and "Economy" in a can; "This Ought To Catch A Big Bunch" he remarks

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Herbert Hoover and Congress leaning back to back, exhausted, with a dismantled Capitol in the background. On verso is a partial sketch of "Miss Democracy," a dog and an unidentified figure

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows a rotund Grover Cleveland in a Shakepearean costume, arm in arm with S.C. Lemly and Shatter, on the way "To The Coronation"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Burleson looking at the "Post Office News" that "Three Letter Mailed To Ollie James From Kentucky on March 6 1914 Have Just Been Delivered"; Burleson comments "So That's The New Service They Promised"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Voorhis, Pepper, Hillman, Biddle, Black and Michelson at the "Political Front" at "Fort New Deal"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Blum, Daladier, Reynaud, an unidentified figure, and Baldwin sitting on the "Has Been" bench; they tell Rayburn, Bankhead, Barkley and Minton "If We Had It To Do Over Again, Boys, We Wouldn't Even Talk Of Adjournment"

did.unittitle: "The 'Numbers' Is Such A Harmless Little Game"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Laws, an unidentified figure and Pine with clubs, beating snakes "Bribery" "Gangsterism" and "Jury Fixing" that slither out of the courthouse

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Congress on a treadmill marked "Social Security Amendment" "Tax Revision" "Neutrality" and "Relief"; Franklin D. Roosevelt holds out a hot dog marked "Adjournment" and tells Congress "Step Faster, Old Fellow, If You Want It"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows old fisherman "Farm Relief" helping little girl "Congress" to row a boat

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam and teddy bear helping "J. Bull" to see the "Panama Republic" through their binoculars and magnifying glass

did.unittitle: "Uncle Sam- I Hope They Won't Be Too Tired To Return For My Little Blowout Next Month"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows crowds running "To The Coronation"; Uncle Sam stands by with a flag and rockets, and teddy bear is shimmying up the flag staff

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Uncle Sam between two farmers urging him to buy and not to buy their wheat; teddy bear shrinks under Sam's money bags as he comments "By Jinks This Is Gettin Embarrassing"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows farmer looking at a picture of teddy bear and Uncle Sam enjoying a rain storm; he comments "Oh Boy! Equalization Fees And Export Debenture Would Have Nothin' On This For Relief!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Norris holding up the placard "Boulder Dam Legislation" as "One Of The Best Things Congress Has Ever Done"; Uncle Sam comments "Hooray! Now I Know It's Christmas!" and teddy bear cheers

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Dr. Jimmy Cox" offering Uncle Sam "Democratic Tariff Bitters" as the "Only Relief"; teddy bear gasps and Uncle Sam refuses, saying "Thanks Doc. I've Tried It!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Stalin Showing Franco to Truman and Atlee, and saying "I Demand That Something Be Done About That Fellow. He's A Threat To World Peace"

did.unittitle: "Squash Center Hears Of Some Words Now Current In Washington"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows locals gathered around a stove, reading words such as "Disingenuous" "Fustian" and "Bumblepuppy"

did.unittitle: "Note- Fight Promoter Rickard Contends That Radio Keeps Fight Fans At Home"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Rickard on the floor crying "Foul!" against a radio wearing boxing gloves

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Congress running away after leaving mean messages at the U.S. Supreme Court's door

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows "Doctors" Franklin D. Roosevelt, Minton, and Norris laying the Supreme Court out on an examination table; they comment "We Merely Wish To Find Out Just What's The Matter With You!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Franklin D. Roosevelt telling Congress to "separate" the mixed cattle in the "U S Business Pen"; Congress replies "Chief, I'd Rather Try To Balance The Budget"

did.unittitle: "Followed Her Into The House Like A String Of Sheep"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows military men being led into a house by a woman

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Davis, Cox and Smith in the office of "Dr. E.X. Aminer" who tells them "You've All Suffered From Bryanitis But Only One OF You Shows Symptoms Of Another Attack"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Smith and McAdoo with a pickaxe and hoe, digging up earth; a placard reads "President Coolidge Sticks To Worms To Catch 'Em"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Robinson and Smith riding donkeys labeled "Wet Democracy" and "Dry Democracy"; Robinson comments "We Must Find Some Way To Turn This Animal Around"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Smith and McAdoo rolling snowballs

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Molotov and Stalin viewing Gromyko and a parade of the UNO, and commenting "Everybody's Out Of Step But Our Boy Andrei"

did.unittitle: "News Note- A Painting Hanging Sideways Won A Second Prize Award Recently"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows the Senate holding up a painting of elephants and donkeys wrestling amid placards marked "Old Guard" "Democracy" etc

odd.head: General note
odd.p: shows Marshall telling Truman "The Russians Are Strange People- It's Hard To Get Them To Agree On Anything"; in the background is the Capitol Building fuming with "Budget Disagreement" "Clash On Taxes"; "Labor Legislation Row" and "Appropriations Fight"
